A staggered setup can definitely give your GT-R a more aggressive stance and improve its drifting capabilities. Just make sure to choose the right tires and wheels for the job, and don't forget to adjust your suspension and alignment accordingly.

It's great to hear that you've been practicing your drifting skills and getting tips from Alex! Alex seems like a knowledgeable guy, and it's always helpful to get feedback from experienced drifters. Controlling speed and angle are crucial skills to master in drifting, so it's awesome that you're focusing on those areas.

Since you're practicing at a parking lot, I assume you're doing some low-speed drifting. Remember to always prioritize safety and follow proper safety protocols when drifting, especially in a public area. Make sure to wear a helmet, keep a safe distance from obstacles, and be aware of your surroundings.

Also, don't be afraid to experiment and try new things, but always do so in a controlled and safe manner. Drifting is all about feeling the car and making adjustments on the fly, so don't be discouraged if you don't get it right immediately. Keep practicing, and you'll eventually develop the skills and instincts you need to become a proficient drifter.

One more thing: since you're using a parking lot, you might want to consider getting some cones or markers to set up a drift course. This can help you practice specific skills, like transitioning between turns or maintaining speed through a corner. Just make sure to get permission from the parking lot owners or managers before setting up any course.

Keep shredding those tires, and don't hesitate to reach out if you have any more questions or need further guidance!
